questions.question: A 35-year-old female presents with persistent flank pain. An abdominal ultrasound reveals that the lower poles of both kidneys are fused. What is the most likely developmental cause of this condition?

options.A: Abnormal migration of the metanephros derivative
options.B: Failure of the ureteric bud to differentiate
options.D: Improper development of the urogenital sinus

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Abnormal migration of the metanephros derivative Explanation: This presentation is indicative of a horseshoe kidney. A condition where the lower poles of the kidney fuse during development. Normally, the Kidney ascends from the pelvis to its final position in the abdomen. Abnormal migration can prevent this ascent and lead to fusion. The ascent of the horseshoe kidney is blocked at the level of the inferior mesenteric artery. Development of the Renal System: Urogenital Sinus: (Option D) Forms the bladder. Forms the urethra. Contributes to the lower 2/3rd of the vagina. Renal System Development Excretory Part Metanephrons Bowman's capsule, proximal convoluted tubules, loop of Henle, distal convoluted tubules. Collecting Part Ureteric bud Collecting duct, minor calyces, major calyces, ureter. Note: Metanephric Mesenchyme: Essential for kidney development. The definitive kidney becomes functional by the 12th week of gestation , i.e., it begins excreting urine. Failure of the ureteric bud to differentiate (Option B) would lead to malformations with the collecting system of the kidney and does not cause horseshoe kidney. Complete degeneration of the pronephros (Option C) is a normal developmental process and does not cause a horseshoe kidney.

questions.question: A 17-year-old girl with primary amenorrhea is diagnosed with Mullerian agenesis. Which all structures are likely to be affected?

options.A: Fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper 1/3rd of the vagina
options.B: Uterus, epoophoron, and lower 2/3rd of the vagina
options.C: Fallopian tube, trigone of bladder, and clitoris

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper 1/3rd of the vagina Explanation: In females, the paramesonephric ducts , also known as Müllerian ducts give origin to the uterine tubes ( fallopian tubes ), the uterus , and the upper one-third of the vagina. Derivatives Wolffian Ducts (Mesonephric Ducts) Müllerian Ducts (Paramesonephric Ducts) In males Ureteric buds develop into ureters, pelvis, calyces, and collecting tubules of the kidneys. Trigone of the urinary bladder Posterior wall of the part of the prostatic urethra Epididymis Ductus deferens Seminal vesicles Ejaculatory ducts Mesodermal part of the prostate Remains rudimentary and forms an appendix of testis In females Ureteric buds develop into ureters, pelvis, and calyces, and they collect tubules of the kidneys. Trigone of the urinary bladder Posterior wall of the urethra Epoophoron Paroophoron - Gartner’s duct Uterine tubes Uterus Upper one-third of the vagina Reference: 1. Langman’s Medical Embryology, 14th Edition, Page 270-272 2. Inderbir Singh's Human Embryology, 11th Edition, Page 284-286

questions.question: A 26-year-old female patient presents to the emergency department in active labour. The obstetrician is concerned about the size of the pelvic outlet and its implications for the delivery of the baby. Which of the following structures is NOT considered a boundary of the pelvic outlet?

options.A: Lower border of the pubic symphysis

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Sacral promontory Explanation: Sacral promontory is a part of the pelvic inlet , not the outlet. Pelvis Components: Structures from anterior to posterior are: Urinary bladder Uterus (in females) Rectum Note: These components are supported by the pelvic diaphragm (levator ani and coccygeus). Boundaries of the Perineum (same as pelvic outlet) : Anteriorly: Lower border of the pubic symphysis (Option A) Arcuate or inferior pubic ligament Posteriorly: Tip of the coccyx (Option C) On each side from anterior to posterior: Conjoined ischiopubic rami Ischial tuberosity (Option B) Sacrotuberous ligament Openings in Perineum Males Females Urethra Anal canal Urethra Vagina Anal canal Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Page 1253-1255 BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page 431,409,410

questions.question: A 35 yr old male with injury to the perineum, presented with blood collection in the perineal area extending to the mid-thigh. Which of the following correctly describes the location and characteristics of the perineal space involved in this patient? and penis

options.A: Obturator fascia and inferior pelvic diaphragm fascia meet to form its apex
options.B: Located below the perineal membrane, open anteriorly, and continuous with spaces in the scrotum
options.C: It contains the urethral sphincter within the wall of the urethra
options.D: Wedge-shaped spaces located below the pelvic diaphragm on either side of the anal canal

questions.explanation: spaces in the scrotum and penis Correct Answer: B) Located below the perineal membrane, open anteriorly, and continuous with spaces in the scrotum and penis. Explanation: Superficial perineal space is involved in this patient. Location: Superficial perineal space is situated below the perineal membrane, which separates it from the deep perineal space. Continuity: It is open anteriorly, allowing for continuity with other anatomical spaces. In males, this includes the spaces in the scrotum and penis, while in females, it connects to the clitoral region. The Colles' fascia fuses with the fascia lata of the thigh, which typically prevents blood from spreading further into the thigh beyond this point. Perineal Regions: The perineum, located between the thighs, contains the external genitalia and is divided into two triangular regions: Anal and urogenital. Region Description Anal Region Contains the anal canal and ischioanal fossa Urogenital Region Contains external urogenital organs Perineal Spaces: Space Description Superficial Perineal Space Located below the perineal membrane, open anteriorly, it connects with spaces in the scrotum/penis (males) or clitoris (females), enclosed posteriorly by Colles' fascia. (Option B) Deep Perineal Space Situated above the perineal membrane, previously thought to contain the urethral sphincter (now known to be within the urethra), it is thin and open above. (Option C) Ischioanal Fossa Wedge-shaped spaces in the anal triangle, located below the pelvic diaphragm, base formed by perineal skin, apex where obturator fascia and inferior pelvic diaphragm fascia meet. (Options A & D) Clinical Significance: 1. Superficial Perineal Space Trauma : Straddle injuries may lead to hematoma or confined urine extravasation. Infections : Common site for Bartholin's abscess in females. Surgery : Involves structures like the penile/clitoral bulb for reconstruction. 2. Deep Perineal Space Urethral Injuries : Membranous urethra rupture can cause urine leakage, often in pelvic fractures. Surgery : Relevant in urethral repairs and sphincter interventions. Incontinence : Damage to the external urethral sphincter may result in urinary issues. 3. Ischioanal Fossa Abscesses : Frequent site for ischioanal abscesses, which may cross the midline. Pudendal Nerve Block : Targeted here for regional anesthesia. Surgery : Key area for drainage of abscesses and treatment of anal fistulas. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Page 1255 BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, Volume 2, 8th Edition, Page 415,417,418

questions.question: In a newborn presenting with ambiguous genitalia at birth, USG reveals the presence of a uterus. The karyotype was found to be XY. What is the most common cause?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Mutation in the SRY gene. Explanation: Mutation in the SRY gene prevents the formation of testes Results in a lack of testosterone and Müllerian Inhibiting Substance ( MIS ). The absence of MIS leads to the proliferation of mullerian ducts ( uterus present ) and the lack of testosterone leads to degeneration of the wolfian duct. Genital System Development: Indifferent Stage: Both male and female structures can develop from common precursors. Intermediate Mesoderm: A major portion of the genitourinary system develops from the intermediate mesoderm. Forms genitourinary ridges and ducts. Genitourinary Ridges: Appears in 5th week of development Give rise to: Testis (in males): Appears in the 7th week of development Ovary (in females): Appears in the 8th week of development Kidneys (although the kidneys develop from the nephrogenic cord, which is part of the intermediate mesoderm, they are closely related to the genital structures during development). Duct Types: Müllerian (Paramesonephric) Duct: Functional in females, develops into the fallopian tubes, uterus, and the upper 1/3rd of the vagina . Inhibited in males by Müllerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS) (also known as Anti-Müllerian Hormone or AMH), produced by Sertoli cells of the testes. Wolffian (Mesonephric) Duct: Functional in males, it develops into epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles , and ejaculatory ducts. ( MNEMONIC- SEED : Seminal vesicle, epididymis, ejaculatory duct, ductus deferens) Regresses in females in the absence of testosterone. External Genital Development by Stage: Arises from the cloacal folds and genital tubercle (not the dorsal somatic lateral plate mesoderm). Male and female external genitalia can be differentiated by 12-14 weeks of intrauterine life. Structure Male Development Female Development Genital Tubercle Becomes the phallus (penis) Becomes the clitoris Urethral Folds Fuse to form the penile urethra Become the labia minora Genital Swellings Form the scrotum Form the labia majora Sex Differentiation: Male Development: SRY Gene: Located on the Y chromosome , it initiates the development of testes. Activates downstream genes like SOX9 and SF1 , which are essential for Sertoli and Leydig cell differentiation. Testosterone Effects: Testosterone, secreted by Leydig cells, stimulates the mesonephric (Wolffian) ducts to form male reproductive structures (e.g., epididymis, vas deferens, seminal vesicles, and ejaculatory ducts). Dihydrotestosterone (DHT): Promotes the development of external genitalia (penis and scrotum). Müllerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS): Known as Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) Secreted by Sertoli cells, it causes the regression of the paramesonephric (Müllerian) ducts , preventing the development of female reproductive structures. Female Development: Absence of SRY Gene: Without the SRY gene, the gonads develop into ovaries . Paramesonephric (Müllerian) Ducts: Develop into the fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper 1/3rd of the vagina . External Genitalia: Develop in the absence of testosterone, forming the clitoris, labia minora, and labia majora . Excessive production of DHT (Option A) promotes the development of male external genitalia. Inadequate expression of WNT4 (Option C) : No role in male development. Increased levels of estrogen (Option D) : Do not present with functional Müllerian ducts

questions.question: A 16-year-old adolescent girl developed secondary sexual characteristics at 12 but has never menstruated. Ultrasound indicates no uterus. Karyotyping and hormone assays are normal. Which structure is most likely NOT affected in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Ovaries Explanation: The presentation is consistent with Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome , characterised by Müllerian agenesis. In Mullerian agenesis, Ovaries are not affected. Ovaries develop from the genito-urinary ridge. Development of the Female Genitourinary System: Müllerian (Paramesonephric) Ducts : Origin : Mesodermal derivative. Developmental Fate : Uterus Uterine ( Fallopian ) tubes (Options B) Cervix (Options D) Upper one-third of the vagina (Options C) Vaginal Development : Upper one-third : Derived from the fused Müllerian ducts. Lower two-thirds : Derived from the endoderm of the urogenital sinus. Urogenital Sinus : Origin : Endodermal derivative. Forms : Urinary bladder Urethra Lower two-thirds of the vagina Mesonephros and Mesonephric Ducts : Mesonephros leaves two mesonephric ducts that open into the urogenital sinus. Mesonephric duct gives rise to the ureteric bud , which penetrates the metanephros, leading to the formation of the collecting system of the kidney. Wolffian (Mesonephric) Duct : Vestigial Remnants (in females): Epoophoron : Located above the ovary. Paroophoron : Found near the ovary. Gartner’s duct : A remnant in the lateral pelvic area. Note: Remnants of the Mullerian duct ( Paramesonephric duct ) in males are the appendix of the testis. Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology, 14th Edition, Page 267-283

questions.question: An 8-year-old male child presents with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging studies reveal a significant dilation of the ureters and an abnormal configuration of the bladder trigone. The patient is diagnosed with vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Urologists suspect that the anomaly is linked to the embryological development of the trigone of the bladder. Which of the following statements about the trigone of the urinary bladder is FALSE? trigone region.

options.A: The trigone is formed from the mesonephric duct.
options.B: The trigone is composed of endodermal tissue.
options.C: The proximal part of the mesonephric duct is the Wolffian duct. Mucosal rugosities are absent in
options.D: The trigone is formed on the anterior wall of the bladder.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) The trigone is composed of endodermal tissue. Explanation: The trigone of the urinary bladder is derived from mesodermal tissue. Development of the Trigone of the Urinary Bladder: Origin: The trigone is formed from the absorption of the tip of the mesonephric (Wolffian) duct into the posterior wall of the urogenital sinus . (Options A & D) Tissue Derivation: The trigone is composed of mesodermal tissue. (Option B) The remainder of the urinary bladder is derived from endoderm (urogenital sinus). Mesonephric Duct: After the formation of the trigone, the proximal part of the mesonephric duct is referred to as the Wolffian duct. Clinical Significance: Anomalies in the development of the trigone can lead to urinary tract abnormalities. Anatomical Significance: The trigone is an important landmark within the bladder , delineating the area between the ureteric orifices and the internal urethral orifice.

questions.question: A one-day-old newborn is admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) due to severe respiratory distress. Prenatal ultrasounds had revealed bilateral renal agenesis and severe oligohydramnios. The neonatologist explains that this malformation occurred early in gestation. Which of the following developmental processes is most likely responsible for the bilateral renal agenesis seen in this newborn?

options.A: Failure of the ureteric bud formation and induce the metanephric mesenchyme.
options.C: Failure of the mesonephric duct to fuse with the urogenital sinus
options.D: Failure of the mesonephric duct to differentiate into kidney

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Failure of the ureteric bud formation and induce the metanephric mesenchyme mesenchyme to differentiate into nephrons (the functional units of the kidney). Hence, failure of the ureteric bud formation or not properly inducing the metanephric mesenchyme leads to bilateral renal agenesis. 1. Collecting System (from Ureteric Bud): Forms: Ureter Renal pelvis Major calyces Minor calyces Collecting ducts (tubules) Potential Issues: If the ureteric bud splits too early, it may result in: Bifid ureter (two ureters) 2. Excretory System (from Metanephric Blastema): Each collecting tubule is surrounded by a metanephric tissue cap , which forms the excretory tubules. Formation of Nephrons (functional units of the kidney): Proximal end: Forms Bowman's capsule, which surrounds a glomerulus. Distal end: Elongates to form the: Proximal convoluted tubule Loop of Henle Distal convoluted tubule Renal System Development Excretory Part Metanephrons Bowman's capsule, proximal convoluted tubules, loop of Henle, distal convoluted tubules. Collecting Part Ureteric bud Collecting duct, minor calyces, major calyces, ureter. Failure of the pronephros development (Option B): The pronephros is the first, most primitive form of the kidney in early embryonic life, but it is non-functional in humans and regresses by the 4th week of gestation. Development or involution of pronephros has no significant role in the formation of the permanent kidneys. Failure of the mesonephric duct to fuse with the urogenital sinus (Option C): A failure in this fusion would lead to malformations of the bladder or urethra, not bilateral renal agenesis. Ureteric bud and metanephric blastema interactions happen independently of this fusion process. Failure of the mesonephric duct to differentiate into kidney (Option D): The mesonephric duct does not directly differentiate into the kidney. It gives rise to the ureteric bud, which then induces the metanephric mesenchyme to form the functional kidney.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs correctly matches the embryonic structure with its corresponding differentiated structure in males and females during the development of external genitalia? → Clitoris (Female), Glans penis (Male) → Labia majora (Female), Penoscrotal raphe (Male) → Labia majora (Female), Glans penis (Male) → Labia minora (Female), Scrotum (Male)
questions.explanation: → Clitoris (Female), Glans penis (Male) Correct Answer: A) Genital tubercle → Clitoris (Female), Glans penis (Male) Explanation: The urethral folds (often referred to as genital folds) develop into the labia minora in females and contribute to the ventral urethra in males. Development of External Genitalia: Structure Female Male Genital tubercle (phallus) Clitoris Glans penis Genital fold (urethral fold) Labia minora Penoscrotal raphe Part of the ventral urethra Genital swelling (labioscrotal swelling) Labia majora Scrotum Reference: Langman’s Medical Embryology, 14th Edition, Page 276-78

questions.question: During a pelvic exam, a gynaecologist is teaching the medical students about the structures of the vestibule of the vagina. Which of the following structures is NOT located within the vestibule?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Clitoral glans Explanation: The vestibule begins just below the clitoris and ends inferiorly at the posterior commissure of the labia minora. It contains the vaginal and external urethral orifices and the openings of the two greater vestibular glands ( Bartholin glands ) and numerous lesser vestibular glands. The clitoral glans is not located within the vestibule. Vestibule of Vagina: It is the area between the labia minora. It is a smooth area that starts just below the clitoris at the top and extends downward to the posterior junction of the labia minora. Contents: External urethral orifice (Option A) Vaginal orifice (Option B) Openings of the two greater vestibular glands ( Bartholin gland ) (Option D) Openings of numerous lesser vestibular glands ( Skene's Glands ) - mucous-secreting glands. Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice, 42nd Edition, Page 1307 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK547703/
